title: Toronto Blue Jays’ Kevin Pillar reveals secret to his great defence: ‘I can fly…for a short amount of time’
text:
KANSAS CITY – Kevin Pillar has finally revealed the secret behind his acrobatic catches. 
“I can fly,” he said, pausing for the laughter to subside. “For a short amount of time.” 
Faithful Blue Jays fans would agree. 
“I mean, I think in the moment when you leave your feet and you watch that ball and you know you’ve secured it, time almost seems to stop, and it feels like you’re in the air for a while,” Pillar said. 
In his first season as a regular, Pillar totalled 22 defensive runs saved, according to Fangraphs.com, which ranks him fifth among major-league outfielders. 
The top four: Kevin Keirmaier, Tampa Bay, 42; Ender Inciarte, Arizona, 29; Jayson Heyward, St. Louis, and Starling Marte, Pittsburgh, 24 each. 
Fangraphs’ data also show that Pillar makes 65 per cent of plays classified as “unlikely” and 12.5 per cent of plays classified as “remote.” 
“I take a lot of pride in and a lot of passion in my defence,” Pillar said as the Jays prepared to meet the Royals in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series. “I know it’s been able to keep me in the lineup when I’ve struggled offensively. And I know our pitching staff appreciates it.” 
Pillar also enjoyed his best offensive season, batting .278 with 12 homers, 56 RBIs and a .713 OPS. He hit safely in his final 10 games of the regular season and 14 of his last 16. 
Entering Game 2 of the ALCS, he was seven-for-21 with a homer in the post-season.
